articles.headline: A Drug Trial’s Frayed Promise
articles.snippet: A study of the drug Seroquel XR for patients with borderline personality disorder exposes the tangled mess of interests for academics and universities involved in clinical trials.
articles.abstract: A study of the drug Seroquel XR for patients with borderline personality disorder exposes the tangled mess of interests for academics and universities involved in clinical trials.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last fall, an article in The American Journal of Psychiatry caught the attention of specialists who treat borderline personality disorder, an intractable condition for which no approved drug treatment exists.

articles.headline: Identity Theft Poses Extra Troubles for Children
articles.snippet: Children’s credit records are clean, and they don’t check their credit reports, two conditions data thieves take advantage of.
articles.abstract: Children’s credit records are clean, and they don’t check their credit reports, two conditions data thieves take advantage of.
articles.lead_paragraph: The note that arrived in the mail, dated March 25 and addressed to my grade-school-age daughter, said what we had expected and feared: Like tens of millions of other Americans, including untold numbers of children, she may have fallen victim to thieves who gained access to Social Security numbers and other personal data from the health insurance giant Anthem.

articles.headline: At Global Economic Gathering, U.S. Primacy Is Seen as Ebbing
articles.snippet: Economists and political leaders see an American government so bitterly divided that it is on the verge of deserting the global economic stage it has commanded since the end of World War II.
articles.abstract: Economists and political leaders see an American government so bitterly divided that it is on the verge of deserting the global economic stage it has commanded since the end of World War II.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As world leaders converge here for their semiannual trek to the capital of what is still the world’s most powerful economy, concern is rising in many quarters that the United States is retreating from global economic leadership just when it is needed most.

articles.headline: Obama Urges ‘Creative’ Talks to Bridge Divide With Iran on Sanctions
articles.snippet: Iranian leaders have insisted in recent days that the sanctions be lifted as soon as a written accord is signed, a position that the country’s foreign minister reinforced on Friday.
articles.abstract: Iranian leaders have insisted in recent days that the sanctions be lifted as soon as a written accord is signed, a position that the country’s foreign minister reinforced on Friday.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Friday directed his diplomats to use “creative negotiations” to bridge a sharp divide with Iran over the fate of sanctions if it agrees to curb its nuclear program, signaling flexibility in hopes of keeping a tentative agreement from unraveling.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Rick Gladstone

articles.headline: Review of Comcast Deal Is Said to Raise Concerns
articles.snippet: The Justice Department staff is said to be leaning toward recommending blocking the merger with Time Warner, but higher officials can overrule any recommendation.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department staff is said to be leaning toward recommending blocking the merger with Time Warner, but higher officials can overrule any recommendation.
articles.lead_paragraph: The staff lawyers at the Justice Department reviewing Comcast’s proposed $45 billion takeover of Time Warner Cable have raised concerns about the merger and are leaning toward recommending that it be blocked, according to a person with knowledge of the deliberations.
articles.byline: By Emily Steel and Ben Protess

articles.headline: After Walter Scott Shooting, Scrutiny Turns to 2nd Officer
articles.snippet: Officer Clarence W. Habersham Jr., who responded to the scene of the police killing of Walter L. Scott in North Charleston, S.C., was criticized by some who said he had not done enough to help Mr. Scott.
articles.abstract: Officer Clarence W. Habersham Jr., who responded to the scene of the police killing of Walter L. Scott in North Charleston, S.C., was criticized by some who said he had not done enough to help Mr. Scott.
articles.lead_paragraph: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — He did not fire a shot. He is black, not white.

articles.headline: Germanwings Crash Exposes History of Denial on Risk of Pilot Suicide
articles.snippet: Investigations have exposed a series of failures and weaknesses throughout the airline industry in dealing with mental illness among pilots.
articles.abstract: Investigations have exposed a series of failures and weaknesses throughout the airline industry in dealing with mental illness among pilots.
articles.lead_paragraph: DÜSSELDORF, Germany — When Andreas Lubitz sent an email in 2009 seeking reinstatement to Lufthansa’s flight-training program after a monthslong absence, he appended what in retrospect was a clear warning signal about his fitness to fly passenger jetliners: an acknowledgment that he had suffered from severe depression.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Kulish and Nicola Clark

articles.headline: At Republican Gathering, All Talk Is of Hillary Clinton (None of It Is Good)
articles.snippet: During a gathering in New Hampshire, an energized, confident bench of 19 Republicans took turns taking apart Hillary Rodham Clinton or competing with her on policy ideas.
articles.abstract: During a gathering in New Hampshire, an energized, confident bench of 19 Republicans took turns taking apart Hillary Rodham Clinton or competing with her on policy ideas.
articles.lead_paragraph: NASHUA, N.H. — They attacked her judgment on resetting American relations with Russia and protecting American diplomats in Libya. They slammed her as secretive for using a personal email account at the State Department and deleting messages in the face of scrutiny. They mocked her recent campaign events in Iowa as inauthentic and her unannounced lunch at Chipotle as antisocial. They even reached back to her husband’s infidelity to disparage her.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Regulatory Relief for Banks That Rarely Fail
articles.snippet: A proposal from Thomas Hoenig of the F.D.I.C. is meant to be a surgical and effective response to requests to reform the Dodd-Frank Act.
articles.abstract: A proposal from Thomas Hoenig of the F.D.I.C. is meant to be a surgical and effective response to requests to reform the Dodd-Frank Act.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rolling back regulations created after the 2008 crisis has been Job 1 for leaders of many of the nation’s large and powerful banking institutions. So it’s no surprise that recent proposals for regulatory reform in the financial industry have overwhelmingly been the work of big banks or their supporters. The bankers want to return to the days when they could roll the dice, pocket their winnings and rely on the taxpayer if something went wrong.

articles.headline: Google’s Steely Foe in Europe
articles.snippet: Margrethe Vestager, the European Union’s commissioner for competition, has a reputation for being tough, but she says it’s her responsibility to make sure that competition is fair and open.
articles.abstract: Margrethe Vestager, the European Union’s commissioner for competition, has a reputation for being tough, but she says it’s her responsibility to make sure that competition is fair and open.
articles.lead_paragraph: Margrethe Vestager, the European Union’s commissioner for competition, who last week took on the colossus that is Google, has a reputation for toughness.
articles.byline: By Natasha Singer and James Kanter

articles.headline: Sale of U.S. Arms Fuels the Wars of Arab States
articles.snippet: A de facto alliance in the region against Iran has opened the way to more sales to Arab states, and raised fears of an arms race.
articles.abstract: A de facto alliance in the region against Iran has opened the way to more sales to Arab states, and raised fears of an arms race.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — To wage war in Yemen, Saudi Arabia is using F-15 fighter jets bought from Boeing. Pilots from the United Arab Emirates are flying Lockheed Martin’s F-16 to bomb both Yemen and Syria. Soon, the Emirates are expected to complete a deal with General Atomics for a fleet of Predator drones to run spying missions in their neighborhood.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Workers Seeking Productivity in a Pill Are Abusing A.D.H.D. Drugs
articles.snippet: Interviews with users and treatment experts suggest a growing number of young American workers are taking stimulants to enhance concentration and stamina at work.
articles.abstract: Interviews with users and treatment experts suggest a growing number of young American workers are taking stimulants to enhance concentration and stamina at work.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fading fast at 11 p.m., Elizabeth texted her dealer and waited just 30 minutes for him to reach her third-floor New York apartment. She handed him a wad of twenties and fifties, received a tattered envelope of pills, and returned to her computer.

articles.headline: Hundreds of Migrants Are Feared Dead as Ship Capsizes Off Libyan Coast
articles.snippet: A ship carrying as many as 700 people sank in the Mediterranean Sea north of Libya, adding to the rising death toll in what has become a migration crisis for Europe.
articles.abstract: A ship carrying as many as 700 people sank in the Mediterranean Sea north of Libya, adding to the rising death toll in what has become a migration crisis for Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — Hundreds of people were feared dead on Sunday after a ship crowded with migrants capsized and sank in the Mediterranean, as the authorities described a grisly scene of bodies floating and submerging in the warm waters, with the majority of the dead apparently trapped in the ship at the bottom of the sea.

articles.headline: Praise and Skepticism as One Executive Sets Minimum Wage to $70,000 a Year
articles.snippet: While the overwhelming majority of the responses on social media and elsewhere were positive, there were also a number of people who expressed doubts.
articles.abstract: While the overwhelming majority of the responses on social media and elsewhere were positive, there were also a number of people who expressed doubts.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Dan Price announced last week that he would cut his own pay and profits to make it possible to raise the minimum wage at Gravity Payments, his credit card processing company in Seattle, to a hefty $70,000 a year, he had little idea of the whirlwind it would stir.

articles.headline: IBM Venture With China Stirs Concerns
articles.snippet: IBM’s partnership with Teamsun, a Beijing company, to provide key technologies is similar to ones it has made elsewhere, but it has collided with political and trade issues.
articles.abstract: IBM’s partnership with Teamsun, a Beijing company, to provide key technologies is similar to ones it has made elsewhere, but it has collided with political and trade issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Shen Changxiang, who once supervised the cybersecurity of China’s strategic missile arsenal and spearheaded computer security research for the navy, has warned of the perils of his country’s reliance on American technology.

articles.headline: Greece Flashes Warning Signals About Its Debt
articles.snippet: That Athens might still be exploring ways to restructure its debt underscores how close the country is to defaulting.
articles.abstract: That Athens might still be exploring ways to restructure its debt underscores how close the country is to defaulting.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — By the standards of his frenzied schedule here last week, the meeting on Friday between Yanis Varoufakis, the Greek finance minister, and Lee C. Buchheit, the dean of international debt lawyers, was a quiet one.

articles.headline: Skip Child Support. Go to Jail. Lose Job. Repeat.
articles.snippet: Though jail is considered an effective incentive for parents who are able to pay, critics say punitive policies do not work for those who are poor.
articles.abstract: Though jail is considered an effective incentive for parents who are able to pay, critics say punitive policies do not work for those who are poor.
articles.lead_paragraph: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — By his own telling, the first time Walter L. Scott went to jail for failure to pay child support, it sent his life into a tailspin.
articles.byline: By Frances Robles and Shaila Dewan

articles.headline: Netflix Is Betting Its Future on Exclusive Programming
articles.snippet: “Daredevil,” the 17th Netflix original series to make its debut this year, is part of an expanding range of original shows intended to position the company for a digital revolution in entertainment.
articles.abstract: “Daredevil,” the 17th Netflix original series to make its debut this year, is part of an expanding range of original shows intended to position the company for a digital revolution in entertainment.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS GATOS, Calif. — It is April 9 just before midnight in the war room of Netflix’s headquarters here, where the smell of popcorn fills the air and a team of engineers, social media experts and other specialists starts counting down the seconds until the new “Daredevil” superhero series goes live on the streaming service.

articles.headline: Service Members Are Left in Dark on Health Errors
articles.snippet: The nation’s 1.3 million active-duty service members are in a special bind, virtually powerless to hold accountable the health care system that treats them.
articles.abstract: The nation’s 1.3 million active-duty service members are in a special bind, virtually powerless to hold accountable the health care system that treats them.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT WAYNE, Ind. — Lt. Col. Chad Gallagher was T. J. Moore’s squadron leader when the 19-year-old recruit arrived for basic training last spring at Lackland Air Force Base in San Antonio. He was watching at the quarter-mile track nine days later when Mr. Moore, on an easy mile-and-a-half test run, collapsed at the finish line and was rushed to a hospital.

articles.headline: Box, Provider of Cloud-Computing Services, Faces Make-or-Break Moment
articles.snippet: Box is nearing a point other young companies are also likely to face: Find a way to cut losses and stay ahead of deep-pocketed competition or disappear.
articles.abstract: Box is nearing a point other young companies are also likely to face: Find a way to cut losses and stay ahead of deep-pocketed competition or disappear.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ALTOS, Calif. — About 10 years ago, Aaron Levie dropped out of college to start a Silicon Valley company called Box. Before long, he was one of those young technology wizards of whom great things were expected.

articles.headline: Changing Tactics, Apple Promotes Watch as a Luxury Item
articles.snippet: The Apple Watch will be sold in just nine countries and only through its own channels, entering the world in a different manner from that of the iPhone.
articles.abstract: The Apple Watch will be sold in just nine countries and only through its own channels, entering the world in a different manner from that of the iPhone.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple has scrapped its usual routine for releasing products with its new device, the Apple Watch. The company is instead taking a page from the playbook of another industry: luxury goods makers.

articles.headline: Pilots Fault Allegiant on Safety as Talks Stall
articles.snippet: The pilots, who are in contract negotiations, say they worry about maintenance problems with the airline’s aging fleet.
articles.abstract: The pilots, who are in contract negotiations, say they worry about maintenance problems with the airline’s aging fleet.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the last decade, Allegiant Air has built a thriving business buying secondhand jets and connecting small cities to leisure destinations like Las Vegas and Honolulu.

articles.headline: Rising Toll on Migrants Leaves Europe in Crisis; 900 May Be Dead at Sea
articles.snippet: The European Union met in Luxembourg on Monday to discuss the disasters as rescuers scrambled to find survivors after ships sank Saturday and early Sunday.
articles.abstract: The European Union met in Luxembourg on Monday to discuss the disasters as rescuers scrambled to find survivors after ships sank Saturday and early Sunday.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — European leaders were confronted on Monday with a humanitarian crisis in the Mediterranean, as estimates that as many as 900 migrants may have died off the Libyan coast this weekend prompted calls for a new approach to the surging number of refugees crossing from Africa and the Middle East.

articles.headline: 6 Minnesotans Held in Plot to Join ISIS
articles.snippet: Federal authorities said a circle of friends in Minneapolis’s Somali community had acted as recruiters for each other and had hoped to travel to Syria.
articles.abstract: Federal authorities said a circle of friends in Minneapolis’s Somali community had acted as recruiters for each other and had hoped to travel to Syria.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For months, as one young person after another in Minneapolis’s Somali community tried to join the Islamic State terrorist group, rumors circulated of a sinister terrorist recruiter who must be luring gullible teenagers and providing the cash to buy air tickets to Syria.

articles.headline: Sale of Cirque du Soleil Aims to Open Doors in China
articles.snippet: Private equity investors agreed to buy Cirque du Soleil for 1.5 billion Canadian dollars, a purchase that will pave the way for the company to expand into China.
articles.abstract: Private equity investors agreed to buy Cirque du Soleil for 1.5 billion Canadian dollars, a purchase that will pave the way for the company to expand into China.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Like many a Vegas act, Cirque du Soleil had become a bit flabby and passé. But a group of investors is betting that China — and more important, its growing demand for Western entertainment — may be an answer to the circus troupe’s midlife ennui.

articles.headline: Europe Is Expected to Bring Antitrust Charges Against Gazprom
articles.snippet: Gazprom is expected to be accused of abusing its dominance in natural gas markets, and countries like Lithuania and the United States have been pushing for a crackdown.
articles.abstract: Gazprom is expected to be accused of abusing its dominance in natural gas markets, and countries like Lithuania and the United States have been pushing for a crackdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European antitrust regulators are expected on Wednesday to charge the Russian energy giant Gazprom with abusing its dominance in natural gas markets, a move that could escalate Western tensions with Moscow.
